Ι observed that almost all the Abipones had black but rather small eyes ; yet they see more acutely with them, than we do with our larger ones3 being able clearly to distinguish such minute, or distant objects as would escape the eye of the most quick-sighted European. Fre- quently, in travelling‚ when we saw some ani- mal running at a distance, and were unable to distinguish what it was, an Abipon would declare, without hesitation, whethenit was a horse or a mule, and whether the colour was black, white, or grey3 and on examining the object more closely, we always found him correct. ⁴

Moreover, in symm'etry of shape‚ the Abi- pones yield to no other nation of America. I scarce remember to have seen one of them with a nose like what we see in the generality of Negroes, flat, crooked, turned up towards the forehead, or broader than it should be. The commonest shape is aquiline 3 as long and sharp as is consistent with beauty. An hundred de- formities and blemishes, common among Euro— peans, are foreign to them.
